member.name: Windows.CreateAppContainerProfile
member.summary: Creates a per-user, per-app profile for Windows Store apps.
member.param: The name of the app container. To ensure uniqueness, it is recommended that this string contains the app name as well as the publisher. This string can be up to 64 characters in length. Further, it must fit into the pattern described by the regular expression "[-_. A-Za-z0-9]+".
The display name. This string can be up to 512 characters in length.
A description for the app container. This string can be up to 2048 characters in length.
The SIDs that define the requested capabilities.
The number of SIDs in pCapabilities.
The SID for the profile. This buffer must be freed using the function.

returns.para: If this function succeeds, it returns a standard HRESULT code, including the following:

listheader.description: The data store was created successfully.
The caller does not have permission to create the profile.
The application data store already exists.
The container name is NULL, or the container name, the display name, or the description strings exceed their specified respective limits for length.

member.name: Windows.CreateEnvironmentBlock
member.summary: Retrieves the environment variables for the specified user. This block can then be passed to the function.
member.param: When this function returns, receives a pointer to the new environment block. The environment block is an array of null-terminated Unicode strings. The list ends with two nulls (\0\0).

param.name: hToken
param.para: Token for the user, returned from the function. If this is a primary token, the token must have TOKEN_QUERY and TOKEN_DUPLICATE access. If the token is an impersonation token, it must have TOKEN_QUERY access. For more information, seeAccess Rights for Access-Token Objects.
If this parameter is NULL, the returned environment block contains system variables only.

member.param: Specifies whether to inherit from the current process' environment. If this value is TRUE, the process inherits the current process' environment. If this value is FALSE, the process does not inherit the current process' environment.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.CreateProfile
member.summary: Creates a new user profile.
member.param: Pointer to the SID of the user as a string.
The user name of the new user. This name is used as the base name for the profile directory.
When this function returns, contains a pointer to the full path of the profile.
Size of the buffer pointed to by pszProfilePath, in characters.

returns.para: Returns S_OK if successful, or an error value otherwise, including the following:

listheader.description: The caller does not have a sufficient permission level to create the profile.
A profile already exists for the specified user.

member.name: Windows.DeleteAppContainerProfile

summary.para:
Deletes the specified per-user, per-app profile.
Note Deleting a non-existent profile returns success.

member.param: The name given to the profile in the call to the function. This string is at most 64 characters in length, and fits into the pattern described by the regular expression "[-_. A-Za-z0-9]+".

returns.para: If this function succeeds, it returns a standard HRESULT code, including the following:

listheader.description: If the method is called from within an app container.
If the container name is NULL, or if it exceeds its specified limit for length.

member.name: Windows.DeleteProfile
member.summary: Deletes the user profile and all user-related settings from the specified computer. The caller must have administrative privileges to delete a user's profile.
member.param: Pointer to a string that specifies the userSID.
Pointer to a string that specifies the profile path. If this parameter is NULL, the function obtains the path from the registry.

param.name: lpComputerName
param.para: Pointer to a string that specifies the name of the computer from which the profile is to be deleted. If this parameter is NULL, the local computer name is used.
param.div: Note As of Windows Vista, this parameter must be NULL. If it is not, this function fails with the error code ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER.

member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.DeleteProfileA
member.summary: Deletes the user profile and all user-related settings from the specified computer. The caller must have administrative privileges to delete a user's profile.
member.param: Pointer to a string that specifies the userSID.

param.name: lpComputerName
param.para: Pointer to a string that specifies the name of the computer from which the profile is to be deleted. If this parameter is NULL, the local computer name is used.
param.div: Note As of Windows Vista, this parameter must be NULL. If it is not, this function fails with the error code ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER.

member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.DeriveAppContainerSidFromAppContainerName
member.summary: Gets the SID of the specified profile.
member.param: The name of the profile.
The SID for the profile. This buffer must be freed using the function.

returns.para: This function can return one of these values.

listheader.description: The pszAppContainerName parameter, or the ppsidAppContainerSid parameter is either NULL or not valid.

member.name: Windows.DestroyEnvironmentBlock
member.summary: Frees environment variables created by the function.
member.param: Pointer to the environment block created by. The environment block is an array of null-terminated Unicode strings. The list ends with two nulls (\0\0).
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.EnterCriticalPolicySection
member.summary: TheEnterCriticalPolicySection function pauses the application of policy to allow applications to safely read policy settings. Applications call this function if they read multiple policy entries and must ensure that the settings are not changed while they are being read. This mutex protects Group Policy processing for all client-side extensions stored in a Group Policy Object (GPO).
member.param: A value that specifies whether to stop the application of computer policy or user policy. If this value is TRUE, the system stops applying computer policy. If this value is FALSE, the system stops applying user policy.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is a handle to a policy section.
If the function fails, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call the function.

member.name: Windows.ExpandEnvironmentStringsForUser
member.summary: Expands the source string by using the environment block established for the specified user.

param.name: hToken
param.para: Token for the user, returned from the , , , , or function. The token must have TOKEN_IMPERSONATE and TOKEN_QUERY access. In addition, as of Windows 7 the token must also have TOKEN_DUPLICATE access. For more information, see Access Rights for Access-Token Objects.
If hToken is NULL, the environment block contains system variables only.

member.param: Pointer to the null-terminated source string to be expanded.
Pointer to a buffer that receives the expanded strings.
Specifies the size of the lpDest buffer, in TCHARs.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.FreeGPOList
member.summary: TheFreeGPOList function frees the specified list of GPOs.
member.param: A pointer to the list of GPO structures. This list is returned by the or function. For more information, see.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call.

member.name: Windows.GetAllUsersProfileDirectory
member.summary: Retrieves the path to the root of the directory that contains program data shared by all users.
member.param: A pointer to a buffer that, when this function returns successfully, receives the path. Set this value to NULL to determine the required size of the buffer, including the terminating null character.

param.name: lpcchSize
param.para: A pointer to the size of the lpProfileDir buffer, in TCHARs.

If the buffer specified by lpProfileDir is not large enough or lpProfileDir is NULL, the function fails and this parameter receives the necessary buffer size, including the terminating null character.

member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.GetAppContainerFolderPath
member.summary: Gets the path of the local app data folder for the specified app container.
member.param: A pointer to the SID of the app container.

The address of a pointer to a string that, when this function returns successfully, receives the path of the local folder. It is the responsibility of the caller to free this string when it is no longer needed by calling the function.

returns.para: This function returns an HRESULT code, including but not limited to the following:

listheader.description: The pszAppContainerSid or ppszPath parameter is NULL.

member.name: Windows.GetAppContainerRegistryLocation
member.summary: Gets the location of the registry storage associated with an app container.
member.param: The desired registry access.
A pointer to an HKEY that, when this function returns successfully, receives the registry storage location for the current profile.

returns.para: This function returns an HRESULT code, including but not limited to the following:

listheader.description: The caller is not running as or impersonating a user who can access this profile.

member.name: Windows.GetAppliedGPOList
member.summary: TheGetAppliedGPOList function retrieves the list of GPOs applied for the specified user or computer.

param.name: dwFlags
param.para: A value that specifies the policy type. This parameter can be the following value.
Retrieves information about the computer policy.
If this value is not specified, the function retrieves only user policy information.

member.param: A pointer to the name of the remote computer. The format of the name is "\\computer_name". If this parameter is NULL, the local computer name is used.

param.name: pSidUser
param.para: A value that specifies the SID of the user. If pMachineName is not NULL and dwFlags specifies user policy, then pSidUser cannot be NULL.

If pMachineName is NULL and pSidUser is NULL, the user is the currently logged-on user. If pMachineName is NULL and pSidUser is not NULL, the user is represented by pSidUser on the local computer. For more information, seeSecurity Identifiers.

member.param: A value that specifies the GUID of the extension.
A pointer that receives the list of GPO structures. For more information, see.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is ERROR_SUCCESS. Otherwise, the function returns a system error code. For a complete list of error codes, seeSystem Error Codes or the header file WinError.h.

member.param: A value that specifies the GUID of the extension.
A pointer that receives the list of GPO structures. For more information, see.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is ERROR_SUCCESS. Otherwise, the function returns a system error code. For a complete list of error codes, seeSystem Error Codes or the header file WinError.h.

member.name: Windows.GetDefaultUserProfileDirectory
member.summary: Retrieves the path to the root of the default user's profile.
member.param: A pointer to a buffer that, when this function returns successfully, receives the path to the default user's profile directory. Set this value to NULL to determine the required size of the buffer.

param.name: lpcchSize
param.para: Specifies the size of the lpProfileDir buffer, in TCHARs.

If the buffer specified by lpProfileDir is not large enough or lpProfileDir is NULL, the function fails and this parameter receives the necessary buffer size, including the terminating null character.

member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

param.para: Specifies the size of the lpProfileDir buffer, in TCHARs.

If the buffer specified by lpProfileDir is not large enough or lpProfileDir is NULL, the function fails and this parameter receives the necessary buffer size, including the terminating null character.

member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.GetDefaultUserProfileDirectory
member.summary: Retrieves the path to the root of the default user's profile.

member.name: Windows.GetGPOList
member.summary: TheGetGPOList function retrieves the list of GPOs for the specified user or computer. This function can be called in two ways: first, you can use the token for the user or computer, or, second, you can use the name of the user or computer and the name of the domain controller.

param.name: hToken
param.para: A token for the user or computer, returned from the,,,, or function. This token must have TOKEN_IMPERSONATE and TOKEN_QUERY access. For more information, seeAccess Rights for Access-Token Objects and the following Remarks section.
If this parameter is NULL, you must supply values for the lpName and lpHostName parameters.

param.name: lpName
param.para: A pointer to the user or computer name, in the fully qualified distinguished name format (for example, "CN=user, OU=users, DC=contoso, DC=com").
If the hToken parameter is not NULL, this parameter must be NULL.

param.name: lpHostName
param.para: A DNS domain name (preferred) or domain controller name. Domain controller name can be retrieved using the function, specifying DS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE_REQUIRED in the flags parameter.
If the hToken parameter is not NULL, this parameter must be NULL.

member.param: A pointer to the name of the computer used to determine the site location. The format of the name is "\\computer_name". If this parameter is NULL, the local computer name is used.

param.name: dwFlags
param.para: A value that specifies additional flags that are used to control information retrieval. If you specify GPO_LIST_FLAG_MACHINE, the function retrieves policy information for the computer. If you do not specify GPO_LIST_FLAG_MACHINE, the function retrieves policy information for the user.
If you specify GPO_LIST_FLAG_SITEONLY the function returns only site information for the computer or user.

member.param: A pointer that receives the list of GPO structures. For more information, see.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call.

member.name: Windows.GetProfilesDirectory
member.summary: Retrieves the path to the root directory where user profiles are stored.
member.param: A pointer to a buffer that, when this function returns successfully, receives the path to the profiles directory. Set this value to NULL to determine the required size of the buffer.

param.name: lpcchSize
param.para: Specifies the size of the lpProfilesDir buffer, in TCHARs.

If the buffer specified by lpProfilesDir is not large enough or lpProfilesDir is NULL, the function fails and this parameter receives the necessary buffer size, including the terminating null character.

member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.GetProfileType
member.summary: Retrieves the type of profile loaded for the current user.

param.name: dwFlags
param.para: Pointer to a variable that receives the profile type. If the function succeeds, it sets one or more of the following values:
The user has a Mandatory User Profiles.
The user has a Roaming User Profiles.
The user has a Roaming User Profile that was created on another PC and is being downloaded. This profile type implies PT_ROAMING.
The user has a Temporary User Profiles; it will be deleted at logoff.

member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.summary: Retrieves the path to the root directory of the specified user's profile.

member.name: Windows.LeaveCriticalPolicySection
member.summary: TheLeaveCriticalPolicySection function resumes the background application of policy. This function closes the handle to the policy section.
member.param: Handle to a policy section, which is returned by the function.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call.

member.name: Windows.LoadUserProfile
member.summary: Loads the specified user's profile. The profile can be alocal user profile or aroaming user profile.
member.param: Token for the user, which is returned by the , , , , or function. The token must have TOKEN_QUERY, TOKEN_IMPERSONATE, and TOKEN_DUPLICATE access. For more information, see Access Rights for Access-Token Objects.

Pointer to a structure. LoadUserProfile fails and returns ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER if the dwSize member of the structure is not set to sizeof(PROFILEINFO) or if the lpUserName member is NULL. For more information, see Remarks.

returns.para: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .
The function fails and returns ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER if the dwSize member of the structure at lpProfileInfo is not set to sizeof(PROFILEINFO) or if the lpUserName member is NULL.

member.name: Windows.ProcessGroupPolicyCompleted
member.summary: TheProcessGroupPolicyCompleted function notifies the system that the specified extension has finished applying policy.
member.param: Specifies the unique GUID that identifies the extension.
Asynchronous completion handle. This handle is passed to theProcessGroupPolicy function.
Specifies the completion status of asynchronous processing.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is ERROR_SUCCESS. Otherwise, the function returns one of the system error codes. For a complete list of error codes, seeSystem Error Codes or the header file WinError.h.

member.name: Windows.ProcessGroupPolicyCompletedEx
member.summary: TheProcessGroupPolicyCompletedEx function notifies the system that the specified policy extension has finished applying policy. The function also reports the status of Resultant Set of Policy (RSoP) logging.
member.param: Specifies the unique GUID that identifies the policy extension.
Asynchronous completion handle. This handle is passed to theProcessGroupPolicyEx callback function.
Specifies the completion status of asynchronous processing of policy.
Specifies an HRESULT return code that indicates the status of RSoP logging.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is ERROR_SUCCESS. Otherwise, the function returns one of the system error codes. For a complete list of error codes, seeSystem Error Codes or the header file WinError.h.

member.name: Windows.RefreshPolicy
member.summary: TheRefreshPolicy function causes policy to be applied immediately on the client computer. To apply policy and specify the type of refresh that should occur, you can call the extended function.
member.param: Specifies whether to refresh the computer policy or user policy. If this value is TRUE, the system refreshes the computer policy. If this value is FALSE, the system refreshes the user policy.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call.

member.name: Windows.RefreshPolicyEx
member.summary: TheRefreshPolicyEx function causes policy to be applied immediately on the computer. The extended function allows you to specify the type of policy refresh to apply.
member.param: Specifies whether to refresh the computer policy or user policy. If this value is TRUE, the system refreshes the computer policy. If this value is FALSE, the system refreshes the user policy.

param.name: dwOptions
param.para: Specifies the type of policy refresh to apply. This parameter can be the following value.
Reapply all policies even if no policy change was detected.

Note that if there are any client-side extensions that can be applied at boot or logon time, (for example, an application installation extension), the extensions are re-applied at the next boot or logon, even if no policy change is detected.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call.

member.name: Windows.RegisterGPNotification
member.summary: TheRegisterGPNotification function enables an application to receive notification when there is a change in policy. When a policy change occurs, the specified event object is set to the signaled state.
member.param: Handle to an event object. Use the function to create the event object.
Specifies the policy change type. If TRUE, computer policy changes are reported. If FALSE, user policy changes are reported.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call.

member.name: Windows.RSoPAccessCheckByType
member.summary: TheRSoPAccessCheckByType function determines whether a security descriptor grants a specified set of access rights to the client identified by an RSOPTOKEN.
member.param: Pointer to a against which access on the object is checked.

param.name: pPrincipalSelfSid
param.para: Pointer to a SID. If the security descriptor is associated with an object that represents a principal (for example, a user object), this parameter should be the SID of the object. When evaluating access, this SID logically replaces the SID in any ACE containing the well-known PRINCIPAL_SELF SID ("S-1-5-10"). For more information, seeSecurity Identifiers andWell-Known SIDs.
This parameter should be NULL if the protected object does not represent a principal.

member.param: Pointer to a valid RSOPTOKEN representing the client attempting to gain access to the object.

Specifies an access mask that indicates the access rights to check. This mask can contain a combination ofgeneric,standard and specific access rights. For more information, seeAccess Rights and Access Masks.

param.name: pObjectTypeList
param.para: Pointer to an array of structures that identify the hierarchy of object types for which to check access. Each element in the array specifies a GUID that identifies the object type and a value indicating the level of the object type in the hierarchy of object types. The array should not have two elements with the same GUID.

The array must have at least one element. The first element in the array must be at level zero and identify the object itself. The array can have only one level zero element. The second element is a subobject, such as a property set, at level 1. Following each level 1 entry are subordinate entries for the level 2 through 4 subobjects. Thus, the levels for the elements in the array might be {0, 1, 2, 2, 1, 2, 3}. If the object type list is out of order,RSoPAccessCheckByType fails and returns ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER.

member.param: Specifies the number of elements in the pObjectTypeList array.
Pointer to the structure associated with the object for which access is being checked.
This parameter is currently unused.
This parameter is currently unused.

param.name: pdwGrantedAccessMask
param.para: Pointer to anaccess mask that receives the granted access rights.

If the function succeeds, the pbAccessStatus parameter is set to TRUE, and the mask is updated to contain the standard and specific rights granted. If pbAccessStatus is set to FALSE, this parameter is set to zero. If the function fails, the mask is not modified.

param.name: pbAccessStatus
param.para: Pointer to a variable that receives the results of the access check.

If the function succeeds, and the requested set of access rights are granted, this parameter is set to TRUE. Otherwise, this parameter is set to FALSE. If the function fails, the status is not modified.

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is S_OK. Otherwise, the function returns one of the COM error codes defined in the Platform SDK header file WinError.h.

member.name: Windows.RSoPFileAccessCheck
member.summary: TheRSoPFileAccessCheck function determines whether a file's security descriptor grants a specified set of file access rights to the client identified by an RSOPTOKEN.
member.param: Pointer to the name of the relevant file. The file must already exist.
Pointer to a valid RSOPTOKEN representing the client attempting to gain access to the file.

Specifies an access mask that indicates the access rights to check. This mask can contain a combination ofgeneric,standard, and specific access rights. For more information, seeAccess Rights and Access Masks.

param.name: pdwGrantedAccessMask
param.para: Pointer to an access mask that receives the granted access rights.

If the function succeeds, the pbAccessStatus parameter is set to TRUE, and the mask is updated to contain the standard and specific rights granted. If pbAccessStatus is set to FALSE, this parameter is set to zero. If the function fails, the mask is not modified.

param.name: pbAccessStatus
param.para: Pointer to a variable that receives the results of the access check.

If the function succeeds, and the requested set of access rights are granted, this parameter is set to TRUE. Otherwise, this parameter is set to FALSE. If the function fails, the status is not modified.

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is S_OK. Otherwise, the function returns one of the COM error codes defined in the Platform SDK header file WinError.h.

member.name: Windows.RSoPResetPolicySettingStatus
member.summary: TheRSoPResetPolicySettingStatus function unlinks theRSOP_PolicySettingStatus instance from itsRSOP_PolicySetting instance. The function deletes the instances ofRSOP_PolicySettingStatus andRSOP_PolicySettingLink. Optionally, you can also specify that the function delete the instance ofRSOP_PolicySetting.
member.param: This parameter is currently unused.
Specifies a WMI services pointer to the RSoP namespace to which the policy data is to be written. This parameter is required.
Pointer to an instance ofRSOP_PolicySetting containing the policy setting. This parameter is required and can also point to the instance's children.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is S_OK. Otherwise, the function returns one of the COM error codes defined in the Platform SDK header file WinError.h.

member.name: Windows.RSoPSetPolicySettingStatus
member.summary: TheRSoPSetPolicySettingStatus function creates an instance ofRSOP_PolicySettingStatus and an instance ofRSOP_PolicySettingLink. The function links (associates)RSOP_PolicySettingStatus to itsRSOP_PolicySetting instance.
member.param: This parameter is currently unused.
Specifies a WMI services pointer to the RSoP namespace to which the policy data is to be written. This parameter is required.
Pointer to an instance ofRSOP_PolicySetting containing the policy setting. This parameter is required and can point to the instance's children.
Specifies the number of elements in the pStatus array.
Pointer to an array of structures.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is S_OK. Otherwise, the function returns one of the COM error codes defined in the Platform SDK header file WinError.h.

member.name: Windows.UnloadUserProfile
member.summary: Unloads a user's profile that was loaded by the function. The caller must have administrative privileges on the computer. For more information, see the Remarks section of the LoadUserProfile function.
member.param: Token for the user, returned from the , , , , or function. The token must have TOKEN_IMPERSONATE and TOKEN_DUPLICATE access. For more information, see Access Rights for Access-Token Objects.
Handle to the registry key. This value is the hProfile member of the structure. For more information see the Remarks section of and Registry Key Security and Access Rights.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.UnregisterGPNotification
member.summary: TheUnregisterGPNotification function unregisters the specified policy-notification handle from receiving policy change notifications.
member.param: Policy-notification handle passed to the function.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call.
